 And, as with many published government numbers, that one is also deceiving. As the US tax base shrinks, federal social expenses are being pushed down to state/municipal levels by reduced tax revenue sharing in the attempt to make federal defense deficit spending appear less ominous. In prosperous times, such a move would be indicative of less federal government, but, unfortunately, those expenses are being relocated complete with cumbersome and expensive federal compliance, operating and reporting statutes. Those unfortunate states without constitutional caps on various forms of taxation are already incurring serious general debt at presently low interest rates to meet their obligations without the requirement of assigning that debt to defined revenue streams. People seem to ignore the fact that it takes X dollars to operate government regardless of where X comes from, revenue or debt. 
 
 All US government spending other than for military purposes and bureaucratic establishments is far below GDP percentages experienced by other industrialized nations. Two results of that domestic policy are the US having the highest per-capita prison population and the highest percentage of consumer GDP spending in that group.

We, as a family, on Monday, November 1, ( the night before the election) dercided that we would have some fun with the next Bush supporter that rang our phone. We planned to keep the next sucker on the phone as long as possible asking questions. It would also be useful to Kerry, we concluded, because as long as we used his time, he couldn't call anybody else. LMAO My first question was about the Social Security reform. First, I asked if there was any magic age where it was encouraged or required or even projected that people would utilize this opt out option. Of course, he didn't know. The plan is sketchy to say the least. His answer was that it's totally optional. Next I pointed out that as a 55 year old, Social Security uses your last 10 years of contributions/earnings to determine benefits. So, anybody at or very near 55 would be a fool to opt out.
